Title: Computer History
Subtitle: Selected inovations in Computer World 1968 - 2010 as picked by random from Wikipedia

Events.Title: IBM PC
Events.Description: The IBM Personal Computer, commonly known as the IBM PC, is the original version and progenitor of the IBM PC compatible hardware platform.

Events.Title: WiFi
Events.Description: Wi-Fi is a way of connecting to a computer network using radio waves instead of wires. It was invented to connect computers that are near each other, and nowadays is much used for Internet connections.

Events.Title: iPhone
Events.Description: The iPhone is a series of smartphones made by Apple Inc since 2007. It does many things that a computer can do, but is small enough to fit in someone's hand.

Events.Title: iPad
Events.Description: The iPad is a small tablet computer made by Apple Inc. Apple first showed it on 27 January 2010.

Events.Title: ARPANET
Events.Description: The Advanced Research Projects Agency Network (ARPANET) was an early packet-switching network and the first network to implement the TCP/IP protocol suite. Both technologies became the technical foundation of the Internet.

Events.Title: UNIX
Events.Description: UNIX is a computer operating system. It was first developed in 1969 at Bell Labs.

Events.Title: Microsoft Windows
Events.Description: Microsoft Windows is a group of several graphical operating system families, all of which are developed, marketed and sold by Microsoft.

Events.Title: World Wide Web (WWW)
Events.Description: English scientist Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web in 1989. He wrote the first web browser in 1990 while employed at CERN near Geneva, Switzerland. The browser was released outside CERN in 1991, first to other research institutions starting in January 1991 and then to the general public in August 1991. The World Wide Web has been central to the development of the Information Age and is the primary tool billions of people use to interact on the Internet.

Events.Title: Linux
Events.Description: Linux is one of the most prominent examples of free and open-source software collaboration. The source code may be used, modified and distributed (commercially or non-commercially) by anyone under the terms of its respective licenses, such as the GNU General Public License.

Events.Title: Netscape Navigator
Events.Description: It was the flagship product of the Netscape Communications Corp and was the dominant web browser in terms of usage share in the 1990s, but by 2002 its use had almost disappeared.

Events.Title: Internet Explorer
Events.Description: Internet Explorer was once the most widely used web browser, attaining a peak of about 95% usage share by 2003.
